Description: Risk fixed % of capital per trade (e.g., 1-2%)
Parameters: Risk % (1-2%), Account size, Stop distance
Best For: Retail traders, systematic strategies, risk control
Implementation: Position size = (Account · Risk%) / Stop distance in $
Advantages: Simple, prevents ruin, scales with capital, consistent risk
Disadvantages: Ignores win rate/payoff, can be too conservative or aggressive

Keywords: kelly optimal-growth edge win-rate payoff bankroll
Description: Optimal fraction: f* = (p·b - q)/b, where p=win rate, q=1-p, b=payoff ratio
Parameters: Win rate p, Payoff ratio b (avg win/avg loss)
Best For: Professional traders, known edge, long-term growth
Implementation: Calculate f*, use fraction (often 1/4 or 1/2 Kelly for safety)
Advantages: Maximizes long-term growth, theoretically optimal
Disadvantages: Requires accurate p and b, full Kelly = high volatility, bankruptcy risk if wrong
Critical For: Traders with edge data, long-term compounding

Description: Size inversely proportional to ATR: Size ∝ 1/ATR
Parameters: ATR period (14), ATR multiplier (1-3x), Capital allocation
Best For: Volatility-adaptive strategies, multi-instrument portfolios
Implementation: Fixed risk $ = (Capital · Risk%), Position = Risk$ / (ATR · Multiplier)
Advantages: Adapts to volatility, same risk across instruments, prevents over-leverage in high vol
Disadvantages: ATR lags, may undersize in breakouts

Description: Exit position if price hits predefined level
Parameters: Stop distance (% or ATR-based), Stop type (hard, trailing, time-based)
Best For: All active traders, risk control, prevent large losses
Implementation: Place stop at entry - ATR·k or fixed %, move to breakeven after profit threshold
Advantages: Limits losses, forces discipline, automated execution
Disadvantages: Stops can be hunted, whipsaws, slippage in fast markets

Description: Exit full or partial position at predefined profit level
Parameters: Target distance (R:R ratio, ATR multiple, fixed %), Scaling (full or partial)
Best For: Trend-following, breakout strategies, capturing profits
Implementation: Set target at entry + ATR·k or fixed R:R (e.g., 2:1 or 3:1)
Advantages: Locks in profits, prevents reversals, defines R:R upfront
Disadvantages: Misses larger moves, premature exits in trends

Description: Stop moves with price to lock in profits, never moves against position
Parameters: Trail distance (ATR, %, fixed $), Activation threshold (after X profit)
Best For: Trend-following, momentum strategies, letting winners run
Implementation: Activate after profit threshold, move stop up by trail distance as price advances
Advantages: Captures trends, protects profits, automatic adjustment
Disadvantages: Stopped out in pullbacks, sensitive to trail distance

Description: Exit position after fixed time period regardless of P&L
Parameters: Max hold time (hours, days, sessions), Intraday (session end)
Best For: Day trading, mean-reversion, decay strategies (options theta)
Implementation: Exit at session close or after N bars/hours if not stopped out
Advantages: Limits overnight risk, prevents stuck positions, good for mean-reversion
Disadvantages: Arbitrary timing, may exit before move completes

Description: Halt trading if account drawdown exceeds threshold from peak
Parameters: Max DD % (10-20%), Calculation (peak-to-trough, rolling)
Best For: Professional traders, institutional risk control, preventing ruin
Implementation: Stop trading if (CurrentEquity - PeakEquity)/PeakEquity < -MaxDD%
Advantages: Protects capital, forces review, prevents revenge trading
Disadvantages: Arbitrary level, misses recovery if stopped too early

Description: Stop trading for the day if daily loss exceeds limit
Parameters: Daily loss $ or %, Reset time (daily, session)
Best For: Day traders, prop firms, risk discipline
Implementation: Track daily P&L, stop all trading if loss > limit, resume next day
Advantages: Prevents tilt, protects capital in bad days, enforces discipline
Disadvantages: May miss recovery, psychological barrier

Description: Limit maximum % of capital in single position or asset class
Parameters: Max % per position (5-20%), Max % per sector/asset class (30-50%)
Best For: Portfolio managers, multi-strategy, institutional
Implementation: Check total exposure before entry, reject if exceeds limit
Advantages: Prevents concentration risk, diversification, limits single-asset blow-up
Disadvantages: May miss best opportunities, reduces conviction sizing

Description: Adjust position sizes based on correlation matrix to control portfolio variance
Parameters: Correlation lookback (30-90d), Target portfolio vol (10-15% annualized)
Best For: Multi-asset portfolios, statistical arbitrage, hedge funds
Implementation: Calculate portfolio variance, reduce size of correlated positions, increase uncorrelated
Advantages: True diversification, controls portfolio vol, risk-parity approach
Disadvantages: Requires correlation data, correlations change, complex calculation

Description: Maximum expected loss at confidence level (e.g., 95% or 99%) over time horizon
Parameters: Confidence level (95%, 99%), Time horizon (1d, 10d), Calculation (historical, parametric, Monte Carlo)
Best For: Institutional risk management, regulatory compliance, hedge funds
Implementation: Calculate VaR daily, limit positions if VaR > threshold
Advantages: Industry standard, regulatory requirement, portfolio-wide view
Disadvantages: Underestimates tail risk (fat tails), backward-looking, model risk

Description: Average loss beyond VaR threshold (tail expectation)
Parameters: VaR calculation + tail average, Confidence level (95%, 99%)
Best For: Risk-averse institutions, tail-risk hedging, stress testing
Implementation: Calculate CVaR as mean of losses worse than VaR, limit tail exposure
Advantages: Coherent risk measure, captures tail risk, better than VaR
Disadvantages: More complex, still model-dependent, requires tail data

Description: Maximum allowed leverage ratio (notional exposure / capital)
Parameters: Max leverage (2x, 5x, 10x, 100x), Margin requirements, Asset class limits
Best For: Margin traders, futures, crypto, leveraged instruments
Implementation: Total notional = Σ(position sizes · prices), Limit: Notional/Equity ≤ MaxLeverage
Advantages: Controls margin risk, prevents liquidation, regulatory compliance
Disadvantages: Arbitrary level, may limit profitable leverage in stable markets

Keywords: greeks delta gamma vega theta options-risk portfolio-hedging
Description: Limit total portfolio Greeks (Delta, Gamma, Vega, Theta)
Parameters: Max Delta (±50), Max Gamma (±10), Max Vega (±100), Max Theta (positive/negative)
Best For: Options traders, market makers, volatility desks
Implementation: Sum portfolio Greeks, hedge or close positions if limits breached
Advantages: Controls directional, vol, and time risk, professional options management
Disadvantages: Requires continuous calculation, Greeks change, hedging costs
Critical For: Options portfolios, derivatives desks, market makers

Description: Simulate P&L under extreme market scenarios (e.g., -10% market, +5% vol)
Parameters: Scenarios (2008 crash, COVID, +/- X%), Frequency (weekly, monthly)
Best For: Institutional portfolios, risk committees, regulatory
Implementation: Run historical or hypothetical scenarios, measure portfolio impact, adjust if vulnerable
Advantages: Forward-looking, captures non-linear risks, reveals vulnerabilities
Disadvantages: Scenario selection subjective, cannot predict all events

Description: hedging delta-neutral beta-neutral market-neutral pairs short-hedge
Parameters: Offset directional risk via opposite positions (short hedge, pairs, options)
Best For: Target Delta (0), Beta (0), Hedge ratio (calculated from regression or Greeks)
Implementation: Market-neutral strategies, long-short equity, options strategies
Advantages: Calculate exposure, take opposite position to neutralize (e.g., short index futures, buy puts)
Disadvantages: Removes market risk, isolates alpha, reduces volatility
Critical For: Hedging costs (borrow, options premium), imperfect correlation, rebalancing
column12: Market-neutral funds, pairs trading, options portfolios

Description: Frequency of portfolio rebalancing to target weights or risk levels
Parameters: Rebalance frequency (daily, weekly, monthly), Threshold-based (±5% drift)
Best For: Long-term portfolios, index funds, asset allocation
Implementation: Check target weights vs. actual, rebalance if drift > threshold or on schedule
Advantages: Maintains target risk/return, prevents drift, disciplined approach
Disadvantages: Transaction costs, tax implications, may miss momentum
Critical For: Passive portfolios, asset allocation, pension funds

Keywords: circuit-breaker kill-switch algo-safety halt runaway emergency-stop
Description: Automatic halt of algorithm if loss, volume, or behavior exceeds threshold
Parameters: Max loss ($ or %), Max orders/sec, Latency threshold, Manual override
Best For: Algorithmic trading, HFT, automated strategies, prop firms
Implementation: Monitor algo behavior, trigger halt if anomaly detected, require manual restart
Advantages: Prevents runaway algos, protects from bugs, regulatory requirement
Disadvantages: False positives, may stop profitable algo, requires monitoring

Description: Maintain equity above margin requirement + buffer to avoid forced liquidation
Parameters: Buffer % (20-50% above maintenance margin), Alert thresholds
Best For: Leveraged traders, futures, forex, crypto margin
Implementation: Current Equity ≥ Maintenance Margin · (1 + Buffer%), reduce positions if violated
Advantages: Prevents liquidation, time to respond, protects from gap risk
Disadvantages: Reduces effective leverage, capital inefficiency

Description: Risk Spreading
Parameters: diversification uncorrelated asset-allocation multi-strategy time-diversification
Best For: Spread risk across uncorrelated assets, strategies, or entry times
Implementation: Number of assets (10+), Correlation threshold (<0.5), Strategy types (3+)
Advantages: All portfolios, institutional, long-term investors
Disadvantages: Allocate capital across low-correlation positions/strategies, monitor correlations
Critical For: Reduces idiosyncratic risk, smoother equity curve, lower drawdowns
column12: May dilute best ideas, correlation changes, over-diversification

Keywords: liquidity slippage volume market-impact bid-ask average-daily-volume
Description: Limit position size relative to market liquidity (ADV, bid-ask spread)
Parameters: Max position as % of ADV (1-5%), Min ADV threshold ($1M+), Max spread (0.1%)
Best For: Institutional traders, large positions, illiquid markets
Implementation: Position ≤ X% of 20-day ADV, avoid if spread > threshold, scale in/out
Advantages: Prevents slippage, ensures exit ability, reduces market impact
Disadvantages: May limit position size, liquidity can evaporate in crisis

Keywords: black-swan tail-hedge crisis-protection convexity put-options catastrophe
Description: Buy cheap OTM options or other convex instruments to protect against extreme events
Parameters: Premium budget (0.5-2% of capital annually), Strike selection (10-30% OTM), Expiry (quarterly)
Best For: Long-term portfolios, wealth preservation, institutional
Implementation: Allocate small % to OTM puts, VIX calls, or tail-risk funds, hold continuously
Advantages: Protects against catastrophic loss, convex payoff in crisis, peace of mind
Disadvantages: Negative carry (premium bleed), may never pay off, timing difficult

Keywords: scaling pyramiding averaging cost-averaging incremental position-building
Description: Build or exit positions incrementally rather than all-at-once
Parameters: Number of tranches (2-5), Spacing (price levels or time), Size progression (equal or weighted)
Best For: Trend-following, breakout strategies, large positions, reducing slippage
Implementation: Enter 1/3 on signal, 1/3 on confirmation, 1/3 on continuation; reverse for exit
Advantages: Reduces timing risk, improves avg entry, limits market impact
Disadvantages: Complexity, may miss move, partial fills in fast markets
